subject: Disable some useless services to make Tizen start faster
commitMessage:
Disable some useless services to make Tizen start faster

These services are not useful in Tizen. However, it still wastes time
as systemd tries to load, queue and start them. And disabling these
services will save some time during Tizen boot-up.

Change-Id: Ic7080030bc6a20469f1adb270c44689c473a1e2a
Signed-off-by: caoxinintel <xinx.cao@intel.com>

subject: smack: Don't follow symbolic links for setting smack labels in /dev
commitMessage:
smack: Don't follow symbolic links for setting smack labels in /dev

When setting the smack label on a symbolic link, the link target,
instead of the link itself was updated. This change correctly sets
the symbolic link label as looks like is intended.

Also this fix is included in the latest systemd implementation in
upstream, coming from 5dfc54615a1eacea18106383c964425cebd67c30 in
git://anongit.freedesktop.org/systemd/systemd, athough it is included
with a number of other changes that are not easily backported.

Change-Id: I1aeef3caad73ccc20efd1f16019740f8a415fde3
Signed-off-by: Kazunori Kobayashi <kkobayas@igel.co.jp>

subject: Add real default.target just like user has
commitMessage:
Add real default.target just like user has

Remove graphical.target as default boot target
and replace it with a real default.target that
will Require either multi-user.target or some
other previously final target. This allows proper
use of default.target.wants.

Change-Id: Ic0a3083dff6b3d398d3fccffcedcba2e30809f87
Signed-off-by: Jussi Laako <jussi.laako@linux.intel.com>

comments.message: Uploaded patch set 1.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Why creating a symlink to a target of choice (multi-user) isn't good enough. It seems there is no default.target (as a file) in upstream repo.

Patch Set 1:

Because then services installed for default.target.wants are not started.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1 Verified+1

I think that this patch is reasonable.
However, Someone else have to approve.

Patch Set 1:

Why not link desired services to whatever.target.wants and default.target to whatever.target? (You might want to put the answer in the commit message)

Patch Set 1:

My thinking has been that least problematic way to change the default target is to keep this default.target and instead of changing symlink, change the Requires=multi-user.target to Requires=graphical.target or something else inside the default.target file if/when needed. This keeps the default.target.wants functional.

Patch Set 1:

On the other hand, you need different services in multi-user.target.wants than in graphical.target.wants. With default.target as link all you need to do is change only one link which makes switching target (especially on a production system) easier. IMHO.

Patch Set 1:

You can keep both as they are, and also default.target.wants if you make default.target a real target that sit on top of either multi-user.target or graphical.target. At the moment graphical.target Requires=multi-user.target. So by editing default.target file you just choose whether you prefer to drop graphical.target or not

So either multi-user.target -> default.target

or

multi-user.target -> graphical.target -> default.target

Patch Set 1:

At the moment, I think none of the services in graphical.target.wants are in any way related to graphics. They just happen to be there for some obscure reason, maybe because default.target.wants doesn't work in current configuration (and there are still couple of services in default.target.wants).

Patch Set 1:

I moved those services from graphical.target.wants to default.target.wants. If you want to move all the services to multi-user.target.wants, then their Requires need to be reviewed carefully, as they can now just assume multi-user.target to be up, but then they would have to require number of specific services instead, so that they are not for example launched before multi-user mode is enabled (ordering inside multi-user.target becomes issue).

Patch Set 1:

Just for reference. In meta-generic package, generic-base.post creates similar default.target for user.

Alternatively I can put the symlink in this systemd package, and delete it in the generic-base.post and set up the normal default.target there. Then both default.targets are set up in same place.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

OK, thanks for explanation I think I am fine with them. Please just put some more information in the commit message.
Uploaded patch set 2.

Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)
Uploaded patch set 3.

Patch Set 3:

Three issues. Primo: the commit message, please fix it according to my previous comment.

Secundo, I should have pointed this out earlier: do not add files in the upstream tree. Put the target file in the packaging directory and refer it in the spec file with the SourceN header and %{SOURCEN} macro.

Tertio: use a more robust scheme to edit the file. Take a look at *.in files and how the editable place-holders are marked or even try m4.

Patch Set 3:

The second comment needs justification. The rest of the changes on the upstream side depends on the existence of default.target. Why do you think the file itself needs to go outside?

Patch Set 3:

I didn't want to go through default.target.in route because it would make number of changes in upstream much bigger. Then I would need to modify configure.ac too to pass the profile to the configure script.

Maintaining minimal changes against upstream is easier.
Patch Set 3: Verified+1

Patch Set 3:

And I DID change the commit message according to the request. What is wrong with the new commit message?

Patch Set 3:

The commit message should start with a *one* line summary. This isn't a technical requirement but rather a convention that enables different tools (git log, gitk, tig etc.) work better.

Patch Set 3:

> I didn't want to go through default.target.in route because
 > it would make number of changes in upstream much bigger.

No it would not. If you:

 1. Save default.target in the packaging directory, preferably as
    user-default.target ( or .in or .m4).

 2. Add "Source2: user-default.target" (or .in or .m4) to the
    spec header.

 3. Copy it in the %setup section.

 4. Customise the file in the %build section

 5. Install it in the %install.

There is completely no need to touch a single line of build-sys code outside of the packaging directory.
Uploaded patch set 4.

Patch Set 4:

Lukasz Stelmach, can u plz review and +2 the patch asap as we have pressing deadline? (it has been modified as you commented)
Patch Set 4: Verified+1
Uploaded patch set 5.
Patch Set 5: Verified+1
Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.

subject: Add inheritable CAP_MAC_OVERRIDE to user session
commitMessage:
Add inheritable CAP_MAC_OVERRIDE to user session

User sessions already have inheritable CAP_MAC_ADMIN permission for setting
Smack labels in application launcher. It seems that also CAP_MAC_OVERRIDE
will be needed to bypass Smack checks during modification of socket labels:

kernel: type=1400 audit(1416390778.371:3): lsm=SMACK fn=smack_inode_setxattr
action=denied subject="User" object="_" requested=w pid=2422
comm="amd_session_age" name="UNIX" dev="sockfs" ino=14108

CAP_MAC_ADMIN only allows policy administration, it doesn't override the
checks.

Change-Id: I7a2dbae2391989d93a0858925d5b15c1ef9a880c
Signed-off-by: Rafal Krypa <r.krypa@samsung.com>

comments.message: Uploaded patch set 1.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Patch Set 1: Verified+1
Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.

subject: Start the user session with capabilities for setting applications security
commitMessage:
Start the user session with capabilities for setting applications security

Include CAP_MAC_ADMIN and CAP_SETGID in inheritable capability set for the
whole user session. All programs started in the session will have this
enabled, unless they drop it explicitly or someone does that in proper
systemd services.
This change alone doesn't give any special capabilities to the processes.
It merely enables them to inherit capability while executing programs that
have those caps in inheritable and permitted sets (+ei).
The above change is meant as a part of solution for setting Smack label and
process groups for applications. Respective application launchers (for now
only Crosswalk) will get file capabilities mentioned above. In run-time
they will call a designated function for setting Smack label and groups and
drop the capabilities.

Change-Id: Ie220e7e0a48f46ca32eacd56c57d9df90cc1249a
Signed-off-by: Rafal Krypa <r.krypa@samsung.com>

subject: Set unit files directory paths in spec file
commitMessage:
Set unit files directory paths in spec file

Unit files directory paths, specified in systemd.pc, are generated from
a default hard-coded value in Makefile.am. On other environments, those
values can be different. Setting those value according to macros in the
spec file allows such cases.

Change-Id: I461981f353fcc35a9eff398c47d403d829ef0477
Signed-off-by: K√©vin THIERRY <kevin.thierry@open.eurogiciel.org>

subject: Set proper smack label for locale.conf to fix TIVI-2890
commitMessage:
Set proper smack label for locale.conf to fix TIVI-2890

The post install script that creates the /etc/locale.conf
didn't set smack label, which defaults to _, and systemd is
running as System, and couldn't write to it.

Change-Id: I3639940d742aa7f20741953ae0268775788d656a
Signed-off-by: Ulf Hofemeier <ulf.hofemeier@linux.intel.com>

subject: Fix changelog entry ordering
commitMessage:
Fix changelog entry ordering

When this package builds in OBS, I see an error message in the build
log:

    error: %changelog not in descending chronological order

This does not happen when building with 'gbs build ...' locally, but
this commit should resolve the issue.

subject: gpt-auto-generator: skip nonexistent devices
commitMessage:
gpt-auto-generator: skip nonexistent devices

The devices we work with have eMMC chips for storage. The chips
provide four "hardware" partitions.  The first is /dev/mmcblk0, it
takes almost whole space and holds a GPT with several real partitions
(/dev/mmcblk0p?). Then there are three block devices (mmcblk0boot0,
mmcblk0boot1, rpmb) that are part of the same hardware as mmcblk0 that
are presented by the kernel as children of the latter. That relationship
makes gpt-auto-generator try to peek them but since they are not GPT
partitions blkid_do_safeprobe() returns -2 making verify_gpt_parition()
function return -ENODEV.

Origin: backport, http://cgit.freedesktop.org/systemd/systemd/commit/?id=843f737a
Change-Id: Ica3f4f02437a92d2b970d8007c4ac60f35906937
Signed-off-by: Patrick McCarty <patrick.mccarty@linux.intel.com>

subject: Run systemd-journald with the hat ("^") Smack label.
commitMessage:
Run systemd-journald with the hat ("^") Smack label.

The journal daemon needs global read access to gather information
about the services spawned by systemd. The hat label is intended
for this purpose. The journal daemon is the only part of the
System domain that needs read access to the User domain. Giving
the journal daemon the hat label means that we can remove the
System domain's read access to the User domain.

Change-Id: Ic22633f0c9d99c04f873be8a346786ea577d0370
Signed-off-by: Casey Schaufler <casey.schaufler@intel.com>

subject: logind: spawn user instance after saving user data
commitMessage:
logind: spawn user instance after saving user data

The RUNTIME variable from /run/systemd/users/UID may not be set by the
time pam_systemd parses the variable to set XDG_RUNTIME_DIR.

This race condition is affecting user@.service in that XDG_RUNTIME_DIR
may be unset in the 'systemd --user' process, resulting in user services
not inheriting the variable.

Fix the issue by spawning user@.service *after* saving user data in
user_start().

Change-Id: Ib3108231655750dd2ea61024bd0ab700e0d1c93a
Signed-off-by: Patrick McCarty <patrick.mccarty@linux.intel.com>

subject: execute: add SmackExecLabel key for services
commitMessage:
execute: add SmackExecLabel key for services

At the filesystem level, setting the runtime Smack label for an
executable is possible by setting the SMACK64EXEC security extended
attribute on the file, but if the runtime Smack label should depend on
the execution environment, the process needs to change its own Smack
label.

This commit introduces a new SmackExecLabel key for this purpose. For
example, 'systemd --user' may need to run with a different label as
compared to 'systemd --system', so SmackExecLabel could be set in
user@.service.

Setting the label will fail if the service lacks capabilities to set its
own Smack label.

Change-Id: I8eb8eb222342c9d0ae7e28530fe7e4d51493b83e
Signed-off-by: Patrick McCarty <patrick.mccarty@linux.intel.com>

comments.message:
Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Verified that this patch works as intended.

See the next commit for the first example, where SmackExecLabel is set for user@.service.

Also, services running under 'systemd --user' will fail to start if setting the key, and the exit identifier is "SMACK", as intended.

subject: Smack - relabel directories and files created by systemd

Systemd creates directories in /dev. These directories will
get the label of systemd, which is the label of the System
domain, which is not accessable to everyone. Relabel the
directories, files and symlinks created so that they can be

subject: Set Smack ambient to match run label.
commitMessage:
Set Smack ambient to match run label.

Set the Smack networking ambient label to match the
run label of systemd. System services may expect to
communicate with external services over IP. Setting
the ambient label assigns that label to IP packets
that do not include CIPSO headers. This allows systemd
and the services it spawns access to unlabeled IP
packets, and hence external services.

A system may choose to restrict network access to
particular services later in the startup process.
This is easily done by resetting the ambient label
elsewhere.

Change-Id: Ia9c8d8744b732b2ee1126d2e446585d16fa56908
Signed-off-by: Casey Schaufler <casey.schaufler@intel.com>

I am not that excited about starting adding smack rules files from packages directly instead of using rpm manifest. 

Casey didn't want this rule added via package default-ac-domains manifest and also since noone depends on that package, it isn't probably included in the image, meaning that from rpm point of view domain System isn't even defined. subject: Run with a custom SMACK domain (label).
commitMessage:
Run with a custom SMACK domain (label).

Allows the systemd --system process to change its current
SMACK label to a predefined custom label (usually "system")
at boot time.

This is needed to have a few system-generated folders and
sockets automatically be created with the right SMACK
label. Without that, processes either cannot communicate with
systemd or systemd fails to perform some actions.

Change-Id: Ie0427422407cd1b7ffa94f6f3b1b918b2c03bb0f

subject: Mount /run, /dev/shm usable to tasks when using SMACK.
commitMessage:
Mount /run, /dev/shm usable to tasks when using SMACK.

Once systemd itself is running in a security domain for SMACK,
it will fail to start countless tasks due to missing privileges
for mounted and created directory structures. For /run and shm
specifically, we grant all tasks access.

These 2 mounts are allowed to fail, which will happen if the
system is not running a SMACK enabled kernel or security=none is
passed to the kernel.

Change-Id: I0b2af620b69f86f5b4a1536959e502b1328c1f27

subject: libsystemd: remove explicit dependency on systemd
commitMessage:
libsystemd: remove explicit dependency on systemd

There is a circular dependency between the systemd and libsystemd
packages; during a package build, the dependency chain is broken and the
installation order may be incorrect.

By removing the explicit dependency on systemd for libsystemd, the
circular dependency is removed.

Change-Id: I887b42ad1870fe04aad0ce694fb6f2bbd3e82772
